Award.AwardTitle: IDR: Collaborative Research: Sustainable Water Resources for Communities under Climate Change: Can State-of-the-Art Forecasting Inform Decision-Making in Data Sparse Regions?

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1014615
Vivoni

This project will study decision-making for water resources management in anticipation of climate change in northern Mexico as a case study for the broader arid and semiarid southwestern North America. The goal of the project is to determine whether water resources systems modeling, developed within a participatory framework, can contribute to the building of management strategies in a context of water scarcity, conflicting water uses and highly variable and changing climate conditions. Local stakeholders will be involved in guiding the design of supply- and demand-side management strategies and selection of climate change scenarios using state-of-the-art engineering tools. These tools include a water resources systems framework, a spatially-explicit hydrologic model, the use of forecasted climate scenarios under 21st century climate change, and observations obtained from field and satellite sensors. The participatory modeling approach will be conducted through a series of interactive workshops, carefully designed to encourage substantive participation from a broad range of stakeholders, including representatives from federal and local government agencies, water use sectors, non-governmental organizations, and academics. The work will evaluate the sustainable outcomes emerging from the climate change scenarios and the potential adaptations that can be implemented in the decision-making process.
The proposed work combines engineering research with social and behavioral sciences for the purpose of evaluating sustainable water management outcomes in a semiarid region in a developing country. Three doctoral level students will be engaged as well as undergraduate students for short-term research experiences. A focus on recruiting Hispanic students (with language skills) will facilitate interactions with local decision makers, regional stakeholders and the general public. The project team will also work with several local universities in Sonora to develop an effective participatory modeling program. The target is for the results of this project to have an impact on water decision-making under climate change in the study area and to provide a case study for replication in other data-sparse, semiarid regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this interdisciplinary project, we developed an approach for the collaborative resolution of water resources management issues in water-stressed basins and extended this approach to consider interactions between water resources management and food and energy consumption and production (food-energy-water, or FEW, nexus). A collaborative modeling platform was developed and implemented in a series of three workshops in Sonora, Mexico, where the existing water supply infrastructure struggles to meet urban and agricultural water demand, even in normal climate years, and is expected to be stressed by increased climate variability as a result of climate change. The collaborative modeling platform included hydrologic sub-models for predicting surface and groundwater availability in response to climate and water demands and a user interface. The sub-models were established based on available hydrologic data, but contain substantial uncertainty given the sparseness of data and parameter values. The user interface, developed deliberatively with workshop participants, allows users to (a) choose from a range of supply- and demand-side schemes for augmenting the existing water supply management system, (b) choose from a range of future climate change and development (e.g. population and irrigated agricultural area) scenarios, and (c) test the effects of hydrologic uncertainty by varying sensitive and uncertain hydrologic parameters (e.g. groundwater recharge rates).  The interface also provided information on system performance, including the ratio of water demand to supply and changes in groundwater storage. Participants experimented with the alternative water resources management schemes, the climate and development scenarios, and parameter uncertainty, in order to design robust management schemes that met participants’ expectations of system performance.

The impact of the collaborative modeling workshop was assessed by developing and conducting pre- and post-workshop surveys, based on conceptual models of participants’ perceptions of regional water-related problems and their underlying causes, perceptions of their own efficacy in water resources modeling, and perceptions of the utility of models for solving water resources problems. The survey results indicate that workshop participants gained new knowledge of the current and future status of water resources in the region. Participants rated the workshops highly, were significantly more likely to feel confident about their abilities to use and understand water resources models, and changed significantly in some of their water quantity and quality-related beliefs. Participants’ beliefs in the significance of water quantity problem impacts decreased over the period of the workshops.  Comments revealed that many participants found the richness of the dialog during the workshops was as important a value of the workshops as was the outcome of the modeling.

The selected water resources strategies and the associated, expected reliability varied widely among participants. Most participants (90%) could be clustered into three groups with roughly equal numbers of participants: A: high reliance on technology, optimistic with regard to impacts, and expectations of high reliability; B: high reliance on technology, pessimistic with regard to impacts, and expectations of medium reliability; and C: less reliance in technology, high reliance on water reuse and residential demand reduction, and willingness to accept lower reliability. The average water supply reliability for the water resources management strategies over all of the climate and development scenarios was 94%. Although the reliability averaged over all scenarios is relatively high, a lower set of reliabilities were found for the more extreme scenarios. For the development scenario with the greatest increase in population and irrigated area and the two driest years, the average reliabilities were 55% and 41%, respectively. The wide range of strategies chosen and associated reliabilities indicate that there is a substantial degree of uncertainty in how future water resources decisions could be made in the region.

The FEW nexus project consisted of the organization and carrying out two major workshops (December 2015 and May 2016) in Sonora on the topic of food-energy-water Interactions. Dozens of participants from the U.S. and Mexico were invited to attend the workshops, representing local expertise in each subject area as well as international experts. The two workshops included 1.5 days of activities that covered theoretical topics, team-building activities and field visits. An organizing principle in the workshops was the impact of a new inter-basin transfer, the Independencia Aqueduct, on the water, food and energy resources of the state of Sonora. Since this aqueduct differentially impacts Hermosillo, the industrial capital, and Ciudad Obregon, the agricultural center, the two workshops were conducted in alternating sites. The main outcome of the two workshops in Sonora, Mexico, was to catalyze collaborations among many institutions in the US, Canada and Mexico on this topic area as it applies to the natural resource supply and demands in Sonora. These interactions have yielded one proposal to NSF, a second pre-proposal to NSF and a series of publications in preparation, to our knowledge. More importantly, the topic of food-energy-water interactions and a systems perspective have been introduced to this region and should lead to additional future innovation.
